reviewText: As always, you can't go wrong with a Jeff Wincott flick.  His acting is above par compared to most martial art stars, and his action and on screen presence are always solid.  Other notable action stars in Martial Outlaw are Gary Hudson (Road House, Circuit) and Stefanos Miltsakakis (Best of the Best 2, Bloodsport 4).The story, I thought was rather enjoyable.  Wincott plays a worker for the DEA, and comes to LA to help out with a major drug import/export industry, which his brother (Hudson) is also working on. Hudson plays a dirty cop, and as the plot progressed, it was interesting to see what would finally become of him.  His betrayal to the LAPD not only affected his work, but his relationship with his brother, father, and wife.  Lots of emotions run that add to the intensity of the story.Martial Outlaw has lots of great action, spread throughout the entire film.  Lots of restaurant fights, shop fights, and good one on ones (mainly between Wincott and Miltsakakis).  The fights are well choreographed and look great.  Most of the fights aren't too short either.For any Wincott fan, or anyone looking for a good solid martial arts flick, Martial Outlaw is highly recommended.  I could easily watch this one over and over.

reviewText: Jeff Wincott is an awesome martial artist. His acting is just OK but the action scenes make up for it. I recommend this movie especially to kung fu flick freaks.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The fight scenes, of which there are many, in MARTIAL OUTLAW are choreographed beautifully with some unique and original slants on familiar martial arts moves.Jeff Wincott looking buffer than ever plays DEA agent Ken White, who is set on bringing down a Russian drug dealer.  Gary Hudson is Jack White, Wincott's older brother who is an LA Cop, a cowboy and unfortunately, a very dirty cop.  Hudson ends up betraying his brother so he can muscle in on the drug deal and wind up with a million cool ones.  Veteran character actor Richard Jaeckel plays their father, a retired cop who wants to be proud of his sons, but has ended up an alcoholic, thanks to his suspicions about his son Jack.Wincott and Hudson perform sincerely, but the end is predictable.  However, the fight scenes work and for a martial arts film, it's above average.  Wincott is one of the better heroes of this genre.

reviewText: In the early 1990s, Jeff Wincott was building a reputation as one of the good guys of B-movie karate flicks, and "Martial Outlaw" is one of the last strong examples of this. Future vehicles would either be more conventional genre action movies (e.g.Killing Man) or would feature subpar fighting content (e.g.Street Law), so personally, I consider this one to be his last hurrah for quality hand-to-hand action. It has some faults, but along with its decent storyline and above-average dramatic output, this is a martial arts flick worth watching for the right audience.The story: DEA agent Kevin White (Wincott) tackles a smuggling operation of the Russian mafia, unaware that his corrupt policeman-brother Jack (Gary Hudson,Bridge of Dragons) is in on the scheme.There are about nine fights in the film, one for every ten minutes on average. Their general quality is the high side of average, though they peak more than once as very good, including during the "Russian circle" scene and the initial brawl between Wincott and Stefanos Miltsakakis (Maximum Risk). The choreography is done by Jeff Pruitt and Koichi Sakamoto, resulting in a solid kickboxing base accompanied by occasionally fantastic stuntwork (just look at how Jeff throws his opponent during the final fight!). Co-lead Gary Hudson is serviceable when it comes to martial arts as well: apparently a real-life practitioner, he's not too great at kicking but picks up choreography pretty well regardless, standing out in a scene early in the flick wherein he brawls with a trio of thugs led by Al Leong (Rapid Fire).Surprisingly, the film was written by five different people. It's not an extraordinary script or story, but it's serviceable in making most of its important characters three-dimensional. Wincott and Hudson have respectable chemistry and work well as brothers-at-odds (though I admit, I spent a good portion of the movie thinking about how cool it'd have been if Jeff's real-life brother, Michael Wincott, had taken the role instead). The direction and production values of filmmaker Kurt Anderson (Bounty Tracker) are both relatively strong: there's no technical reason this one oughtn't have gotten a theatrical release. Dramatic portions from the supporting cast are good: the mob boss played by Vladimir Skomarovsky (Black Eagle) is entertaining to watch, and the film constitutes the final movie appearance by Oscar-nominee Richard Jaeckyl (The Dirty Dozen), who does well in a limited role.Not much more to say about this one. Wincott fans shouldn't hesitate to pick this one up, even if it is only available on VHS at this point.

reviewText: In the early 90s, a whole glut of great kick flicks arrived, or as I like to call them American chopsocky. The video store walls were lined with this titles, both theatrical realses with the likes of Steven Seagal or Jean-Claude Van Damme, and the original direct to video stars like Don "the Dragon" Wilson and Cynthia Rothrock. One of the best in the latter category was Jeff Wincott, a Candian martial artist who followed his brother Michael into the film arena (Michael is best known as the main baddie in The Crow), Jeff made many superior fight flicks, with Martial Outlaw being one of his best.Jeff stars as a DEA agent, who comes home to LA while on a case, o find his father a cripple with a even more crippling drinking problem and his brother, a cop, is on the take. Jeff is there to take down a section of the Russian mob, but his bro is actually in bed with them. The two brothers have some other kinda beef, I'm not totally sure what it was, resentment for abandoning him with there father, or a history with his wife is hinted at.The story is pretty standard, that's the name of the game with action flicks, each one the same, just dressed up with new violent action scenes. Martial Outlaw dosn't disapoint when it comes to the action, the fights are truely superb, and very exciting. As someone who looks back at this genre with fond memories, Martial Outlaw offers some of the finest.

reviewText: Being inspired by some recent pony-tailed justice, courtesy of Lorenzo Lamas, we have decided to partake in some more enlightening 90's action. With all the many choices just waiting to be picked we had to go with Martial Outlaw. Maybe it was the shirtless Bonaduce on the cover that won us over, or maybe it was the stereotypical 90's b action plot, or maybe it was a million other reasons. Whatever it was, we just knew Martial Outlaw would be yet another winner. When it comes to the action of the 90's there simply is no losers. The movie stars Jeff Wincott who appears to be the Chuck Norris of Canada. Let us tell you...this guys got it! Jeff was clearly bred to be a 90's action powerhouse, and we fully plan to acquire the rest of his low budget features. In fact has now been become a priority which may result in us missing work for a while.Martial Outlaw opens up with a sting operation in a poorly lit parking lot. When things heat up, DEA agent Kevin white (Wincott) steps in a annihilates three street toughs with his fists of fury. He obtains one of the men in order to have him snitch out a Russian Mob he's working for. Obviously the pawn is quite scared knowing the ruthless mob, from the glorious country of Kazakhstan, will snap off his c--- if he's caught. However agent White and his abs of steel promise his life will not be in danger. This leads to the DEA working with the LAPD in which White's brother works for. It must be great to have a brother duo taking on the Kazakh killers right? Wrong! Turns out White's brother is in bed with the mob, a very crooked individual. It also doesn't help that the brothers can't stand each other and duke it out every ten minutes. This was quite hilarious. Especially for the fact half the time they had no shirts on. As White attempts to take down the mob, his brother tips them off before he has the chance. Eventually the cat is out of the bag forcing a mind-numbing final scene demolishing the Russian mob. Not even their gypsy tears could protect them form the brute force of agent White.If it isn't obvious, we considered Martial Outlaw to be a GREAT SUCCESS! Between The Final Sacrifice, Gordon Lightfoot, and Martial Outlaw, Canada is being viewed in an entirely new light. There is an abundance of talent flowing through the maple syrup there, and we will guzzle it by the gallons. Despite every plot being nearly identical, the B of the 90's yet again proves itself to be dominant in its weight class. There is no shortage of low budget magic to enjoy from this epic decade. If they say laughter is the best medicine then we need to prescribe B to those will ailments STAT. These films are honestly a cure all for any situation in life. If you're having any issues you need to devote a little time to some sweet action B of the 90's. If you don't spend the entire hour and a half in tears then we will eat our words....well actually we won't, but you get the idea.
summary: Rowsdower's not the only shinning star from Canada any longer
